column1: Unless we extend the eviction moratorium millions of Americans will become homeless in the middle of winter. Many of them will die. This is not complicated. This is about saving lives in the middle of a pandemic that worsens every day.  https://t.co/4So3hXiEDb

The unemployment protections passed in the CARES Act expire the morning after Christmas. Before that happens we must fully reinstate and extend Pandemic Unemployment Assistance and make sure all workers including gig workers are protected through this crisis.

In Massachusetts on this 400th anniversary of the Mayflower's arrival we continue to stand with the Wampanoag people who first met the Pilgrims and celebrate their continued sovereignty and land rights.

While we celebrate all that we are grateful for today we must also remember the true history of Thanksgiving and recognize the atrocities committed against Native Americans as well as the widespread disease brought by European arrival which decimated the Native population.

Our agenda aims to target the interlocking crises of racial economic and climate injustice. We must invest in and strengthen new public institutions to ensure that all people and communities have the resources that they need to thrive.

We must support struggling workers and families through these crises. We will ensure that any workers displaced by the climate crisis pandemic or other economic shocks will receive full pay and benefits and equitable job placement in new industries.

We have fewer than 10 years to take bold and urgent action to protect our planet from irreversible damage from the climate crisis. Our plan calls for a clean energy revolution to prevent climate disasters and save our future.

We have seen the devastating health impacts of pollution environmental degradation and poor air quality on our communities. We must end this environmental injustice and ensure that all people are guaranteed clean water clean air and the resources they need to stay healthy.

It is long past due that our government recognize the sovereignty of Native Nations. Our agenda calls for strengthening tribal sovereignty enforcing native treaty rights and ensuring that indigenous peoples are equal partners in decisions that impact their communities or land.

We must focus our investments on the communities that have been hurt the most. The THRIVE agenda calls for 40% of investments to go to BIPOC working class and frontline communities and gives these communities authority to democratically plan and implement new projects.
One job should be enough. It’s time to give all workers access to unions and ensure that every job provides the benefits that workers and families need to survive and thrive.

We have a responsibility to stand with the disability community and demand justice. Together we can and will build a more inclusive equitable and accessible country.

When it comes time for elections the disability community faces extraordinary barriers to exercising their right to vote. Most polling places are not ADA compliant. This is voter suppression. Equal access to our democracy is non-negotiable.

This pandemic has been challenging for students and families across the country. But the burden falls even greater on students with disabilities who are being denied the services they need during this crisis. We cannot continue to let these students fall between the cracks.

The sub-minimum wage is a legal loophole that allows organizations to pay workers with disabilities a fraction of what their non-disabled coworkers are paid—even below the federal minimum wage. We must end this injustice and raise the minimum wage to at least $15 for all people.

About one third to one half of all people killed by police have a disability. When we talk about addressing systemic racism and police brutality it is crucial that the disability community is central to and included in the conversation. #BlackDisabledLivesMatter
Advocacy for the disability community cannot stop at simply expanding accessibility. We must fight to guarantee racial social and economic justice for all.

This Sunday we marked the 30th anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act. This act codified important rights for people with disabilities. But the ADA in its current form is not enough to provide the disability community with the protections and resources they need.

Today is the last day of Disability Pride Month. We celebrate the disability activists who fought to pass the monumental Americans with Disabilities Act and honor their work by continuing the fight to expand disability rights. This is a year round struggle.

In 1998 my mother passed away. The next year I founded the bipartisan Congressional Task Force on Alzheimer’s Disease. I owed it to her my father and all those affected by Alzheimer’s to help fight for a cure.

In 1985 my mother was diagnosed with Alzheimer’s. For thirteen years my father cared for her in our home. And for thirteen years while I was a congressman I helped him. We joined the ranks of 16 million unpaid caregivers nationwide who care for loved ones with Alzheimer’s.

The Nuclear Freeze Movement began the end of the arms race. It was regular people concerned about their communities their children the future of our country and our planet who rose up organized demanded change and won.
It changed the whole tenor of negotiations between the United States and the USSR. It drove Ronald Reagan back to the negotiating table.
On May 4 1983 the Nuclear Freeze Resolution passed the House with broad bipartisan support. By 1984 it was a part of the Democratic Presidential Party Platform.

By the fall of 1982 nuclear freeze referenda appeared on the ballot in 10 states and 37 cities and counties across the country. In all but 1 of the states and 3 of the localities voters delivered a resounding victory for nuclear freeze.

Ronald Reagan fought us. The Pentagon fought us. The arms manufacturers fought us. Our Nuclear Freeze Resolution was narrowly defeated in the House. But the public rallied around this call for bold and urgent action.

On June 12 1982—the same day as the UN Special Session on Disarmament—1 million people stood with us to demand a nuclear freeze. That rally is still the largest peace protest in the history of the United States. The message we sent that day was clear: no more nukes.

In March of 1982 Randy and I partnered to introduce the Nuclear Freeze Resolution in the House of Representatives. By June there was enough momentum around the nuclear freeze that one million people showed up in Central Park to protest Reagan’s nuclear buildup.

The Nuclear Freeze campaign was the idea of a brilliant woman named Randall Forsberg. It called for a halt on the production deployment and testing of nuclear weapons in the United States and the Soviet Union so we could prevent senseless nuclear catastrophe.

The arms race was the greatest existential threat our planet had ever faced. The US and USSR had enough atomic weapons to destroy the world a hundred times over.   People were frightened. But across the country people began to say enough is enough. We began to organize.

When Ronald Reagan took over as president he suspended all negotiations with the Soviet Union over arms control and began to build an arsenal of nuclear weapons. The Soviet Union responded in kind. Before long we were in a full blown nuclear arms race. https://t.co/ExMWSo3LB6

Today the Supreme Court declared that the Civil Rights Act of 1964 prohibits discrimination based on gender identity & sexual orientation. From now on the law will reflect what we have always known to be true—our LGBTQ+ siblings are entitled to equal protection under the law.

Qualified immunity forces victims and their families into an unjust Catch-22 with most cases dismissed outright.   Many victims will not even try to make their case due to this impossible burden.   The system is rigged.

Today victims of police violence cannot file suit unless they can identify a previous case where the use of force they suffered was ruled illegal. It must be in the same jurisdiction the same context and the same conduct.

Qualified immunity is not a law but a judge-made doctrine designed to dismantle the Civil Rights Act of 1871 which allowed people to sue public officials including police who infringe on their fundamental rights.

Qualified immunity is one of the foremost tools of racist oppression. It is a legal doctrine that protects police from being sued and held liable by victims of police violence effectively shielding officers from accountability.

The fight is not over. The internet should be open chaotic and democratic and that is why we must continue to organize to save net neutrality and guarantee internet for all.

The Trump administration has consistently sought to undermine net neutrality. In 2017 Trump appointed Ajit Pai a former Verizon lawyer as the chairman of the FCC. As expected Trump and Pai immediately got to work dismantling net neutrality protections.

But we do not agonize we organize. So I immediately introduced a bill and mounted a successful public pressure campaign to get the FEC to reclassify broadband providers under Title II—and restore net neutrality.
In 2010 the FCC approved the Open Internet order which mandated net neutrality policies though just four years later a court order would effectively kill these protections.

In 2006 I brought the first ever net neutrality bill to the floor. Three years later I passed an amendment to the Recovery Act of 2009 that created a national plan to guarantee broadband for all. https://t.co/JUVi8Coz8d

I started fighting for net neutrality before most members of Congress knew what it was. And I made a lot of enemies along the way—big corporations and private interests who sought to carve up the internet and take advantage of consumers.
The internet is an essential part of our lives now more than ever before and I have spent my career fighting for a free and open internet for all.

Black Americans account for only 13% of the population but represent a third of all deaths from COVID-19. They are being killed at nearly three times the rate as other demographic groups.

Debemos ser un gobierno del pueblo por el pueblo y para el pueblo.
Debemos asegurarnos de que todos tengan voz en nuestro gobierno. El New Deal for New Americans fortalecerá nuestra democracia a través del registro automático de nuevos ciudadanos.
También crearemos una beca para el desarrollo del esfuerzo laboral que le da a los refugiados los recursos que necesitan para tener éxito.

Debemos dar a todos una oportunidad igual de alcanzar el sueño americano. Por eso crearemos un programa de educación en inglés para ayudar a los trabajadores inmigrantes a obtener un diploma de equivalencia de escuela superior y prepararse para la naturalización.

Para cumplir con la promesa de nuestra nación de proveer justicia igualitaria bajo la ley crearemos un fondo de ayuda legal para los inmigrantes para asegurar que todos conozcan sus derechos y tengan los recursos para ejercerlos.

Mientras aspiramos a alcanzar las palabras inscritas en la Estatua de la Libertad–“Denme sus masas cansadas pobres y acurrucadas que anhelan respirar libres”–aumentaremos la cuota de admisión de refugiados y pondremos fin a la norma discriminatoria de la carga pública.

Necesitamos un camino hacia la ciudadanía para todos. El New Deal for New Americans creará una oficina ejecutiva en la Casa Blanca para reducir las barreras a la ciudadanía y promover y apoyar la inclusión de inmigrantes y refugiados.  https://t.co/WiBAyvAYuH

We must be a government of the people by the people and for the people.
We must ensure that everyone has a voice in our government.  The New Deal for New Americans will strengthen our democracy through automatic voter registration of new citizens.

We must give everyone an equal shot at the American Dream.  That’s why we will create an English education program to help immigrant workers earn a GED and prepare for naturalization and a Workforce Development Grant that gives refugee the resources they need to succeed.

To fulfill our nation’s promise to provide equal justice under the law we will create a legal aid fund for immigrants to ensure that everyone knows their rights and has the resources to exercise them.

As we aspire to live up to the words inscribed on the Statue of Liberty—”Give me your tired your poor your huddled masses yearning to breathe free”—we will raise the quota for refugee admissions and put an end to the discriminatory public charge rule.

We need a pathway to citizenship for all. The New Deal for New Americans will create an executive office in the White House to reduce barriers to citizenship and promote and support immigrant and refugee inclusion. https://t.co/UCedYIw8vg

Thank you to the activists and organizers who came out to caucus this weekend. For the fourth week in a row we saw wins across the state that demonstrate the strength of our movement. https://t.co/Hskw72hR2N

Yet the women’s movement is stronger than ever. In 2018 a record shattering number of women ran for office–and won. They are paving the way for future female leaders and a more representative and just democracy.
Women hold fewer than 25% of seats in Congress. And even though a record number of women ran for the presidency this year we still have yet to elect our first female president.

Meanwhile abortion rights are under attack. After nearly 50 years of precedent Roe v. Wade is as close as it has ever come to being rolled back and funding for reproductive healthcare services is being slashed.

Women also face discrimination in the health system. Women’s pain is taken less seriously than men’s and the concerns of women of color in particular are regularly dismissed by providers. The maternal mortality rate for black women is more than 3 times that of white women.

Women still make 77 cents on average to a man’s dollar. Black women make 63 cents to a white man’s dollar. Latinas make 53 cents to a white man’s dollar. If we closed the gender pay gap we could cut the poverty rate for working women and their families in half.

Gender based discrimination impacts all aspects of a woman’s life from the personal to the professional and the political. We will fight for social and economic justice and guarantee women’s rights and autonomy. #InternationalWomensDay https://t.co/GccRzLBhLN

But women are leading the way toward peace. Pakistani activist @Malala defends girls’ education in the face of war. Climate activist @JaneFonda also speaks out against global conflict. And closer to home @marudehar and @masspeaceaction push for more peaceful US foreign policy.
Conflict also drives gender based discrimination and inequity. During periods of violence girls are often taken out of schools or prevented from receiving an education.

Women make up the largest share of refugees and people displaced by conflict. Displaced women and those in conflict areas are more vulnerable to physical and sexual abuse. One in five refugee women is estimated to have experienced sexual violence.

It is estimated that about 70% of those killed in today’s conflicts are civilians mainly women and children. As of November 2019 335000 civilians in Iraq Afghanistan Yemen Syria and Pakistan were killed as a result of war.

Women are often the ones most affected by war and conflict. We will fight to put a stop to endless wars end nuclear proliferation and create a free and peaceful world for all. #InternationalWomensDay https://t.co/Hwbooi5VxQ

But women are also leading the movement to end gun violence. From @MomsDemand to Congresswoman @lucymcbath to former Congresswoman @GabbyGiffords and @ChaplainChery women are rising up to demand an end to the epidemic of gun violence in our country.
Women in the United States are 21 times more likely to die from firearm homicides than women in other wealthy nations.

On average 52 women are shot and killed by an intimate partner per month. Nearly 1 million American women alive today have reported being shot or shot at by an intimate partner. 4.5 million have been threatened with a gun.

Gun violence is inextricably tied to intimate partner violence and violence against women. We must commit to passing common sense gun safety legislation and universal background checks to keep guns out of the hands of abusers and end gun violence. #InternationalWomensDay https://t.co/tEjcwgRaTv

Women and girls are also leading the fight to combat the climate crisis. @VarshPrakash founded the Sunrise Movement. @GretaThunberg is a leader of the climate movement worldwide. And other groups like @MothersOutFront are leading the fight for environmental justice.

Pollution and contamination contribute to worsening health particularly for women. The growing prevalence of asthma for teen girls is attributed to the climate crisis. Rising temperatures food insecurity & other symptoms of the climate crisis increase maternal mortality rates.
Extreme weather events disproportionately affect poor populations. Women make up 70% of the world’s poor.   80% of people displaced by climate change are women.
Environmental destruction fuels violence against women and contributes to conflicts and war.

Globally women face the harshest consequences of the climate crisis. We will fight to pass a Green New Deal and stand up for environmental justice everywhere. #InternationalWomensDay https://t.co/3THzjkO18Y

When injustice occurs it hits women the hardest. This International Women's Day we recognize the threats that women face around the world commit to fighting for a world free of these injustices and celebrate the women who are already leading the way. #InternationalWomensDay https://t.co/7CGCSTHvju
